Introduction

Vertigo is a sensation of motion when no motion is present or an exaggerated sense of motion for a given bodily movement; it is often described as a spinning, whirling, or tilting sensation.  Peripheral vertigo arises from pathologies affecting the vestibular system in the inner ear, whereas central vertigo is related to central nervous system (CNS) abnormalities, primarily affecting the brainstem or cerebellum.  This distinction is crucial, as the underlying conditions range from benign to potentially life-threatening, requiring different diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

Pathophysiology



Vertigo arises from disruptions in the vestibular system, responsible for balance and spatial orientation.  The vestibular system also plays an important role in maintaining gaze as the head moves through the vestibuloocular reflex, which is why nystagmus often accompanies vertigo.  The vestibular system starts with detection of the body's sense of balance in the structures of the inner ear (

figure 1
).  The inner ear contains:



  • Cochlea, which has endolymphatic fluid and is the sensory organ of hearing
  • Semicircular canals, which contain endolymphatic fluid and sense head rotation
  • Otolith organs (eg, utricle and saccule), which are crystal-filled structures that sense horizontal and vertical acceleration


The relative movement of the endolymphatic fluid stimulates hair cells, which generate electrical impulses that are transmitted to the brain via the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) (

figure 2
).  Peripheral vertigo usually occurs due to damage to the semicircular canals or otolith organs, which leads to abnormal or conflicting sensory input to the brain, interpreted as motion.



The vestibulocochlear nerve travels into the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle (

figure 3
) at the junction of the pons and medulla; in the brainstem, it sends signals to the vestibular nuclei and to nuclei of ocular muscles.  These signals then travel to the cortex and the cerebellum (particularly in the inferior vermis and flocculonodular lobe) where information about balance and maintenance of gaze can be processed.  Central vertigo typically occurs due to damage in this part of the pathway.

Causes of peripheral vertigo



Peripheral vertigo, which is much more common than central vertigo, can be due to a variety of causes affecting the inner ear structures and vestibulocochlear nerve.  The most common causes, including benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), MÃ©niÃ¨re disease, and vestibular neuritis, will be briefly discussed here.  Other causes can include herpes zoster oticus, perilymphatic fistulas, and aminoglycoside toxicity.

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo



BPPV is the most common cause of vertigo and is attributed to canalithiasis, or the presence of crystalline debris (canaliths) in the semicircular canals.  These canaliths disrupt the normal flow of fluid in the semicircular canals, leading to contradictory signals from the corresponding canals to the brain, causing vertigo.  Clinically, the vertigo of BPPV presents as:



  • Brief (<1 min), recurrent episodes associated with nausea
  • Vertigo triggered by head position changes (eg, rolling over in bed)
  • Positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: video 1
    ).  This maneuver can help diagnose BPPV; vertigo and nystagmus are triggered as the patient quickly lies back into a supine position with the head rotated 45 degrees.


Patients with BPPV do not typically have hearing loss because the pathology is isolated to the semicircular canals.  The diagnosis is based on clinical features and no further work-up is needed in those with classic presentations.  Treatment with canalith repositioning maneuvers, such as the Epley maneuver (

ðŸ“Š View Table: video 2
), which try to guide free-floating canaliths back into the utricle, is typically effective.

MÃ©niÃ¨re disease



MÃ©niÃ¨re disease is a disorder of the inner ear characterized by increased volume and/or pressure of endolymph (endolymphatic hydrops) that is thought to be due to defective resorption of endolymph.  The resulting distension of the endolymphatic system causes damage to both the semicircular canals and cochlea of the inner ear.  MÃ©niÃ¨re disease is characterized by the following triad:



  • Episodic vertigo lasting 20 minutes to 24 hours, commonly associated with nausea and vomiting
  • Sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus, which is usually unilateral and will fluctuate and vary in severity, though it will often worsen over time.  It primarily affects low frequencies at first and progresses to permanent loss over all frequencies.
  • Aural fullness, a sensation of pressure or fullness in the affected ear


The diagnosis is typically clinical, supported by hearing loss on auditory testing.  Diet and lifestyle modifications are first-line therapy for MÃ©niÃ¨re disease.  If lifestyle modifications fail to control symptoms, diuretics (eg, hydrochlorothiazide) and/or vasodilators (eg, betahistine) are often used.  Vestibular suppressants (eg, meclizine, clonazepam) and/or antiemetics can be used during acute attacks but are not helpful as daily preventive therapy.

Vestibular neuritis



Vestibular neuritis (VN) is an inflammatory disorder affecting the vestibular branch of the CN VIII that sometimes follows a viral infection.  Clinically, VN presents with:



  • Acute, sustained vertigo that may last for days.  It can be associated with significant nausea/vomiting and gait impairment, with patients swaying toward the affected side.
  • Nystagmus (usually horizontal) that is suppressed with visual fixation
  • Positive head impulse test, in which the patient attempts to maintain focus on a distant target while the head is rapidly rotated left and then right.  Patients with normal vestibular function can keep their eyes on target.  However, patients with a peripheral vestibular lesion such as VN have their eyes dragged off target by head rotation toward the lesion followed by a corrective saccade back to target.


VN combined with unilateral hearing loss is termed labyrinthitis (concurrent cochlear branch and/or labyrinth involvement).  Diagnosis of VN is based on clinical findings and a positive head impulse test.  VN is usually self-limited, and patients can typically be managed symptomatically with vestibular suppressants (eg, meclizine) and antiemetics.  Corticosteroids may improve short-term recovery, and vestibular rehabilitation can improve residual imbalance.

Causes of central vertigo



Central vertigo is typically caused by disruption of vestibular fibers in the brainstem or cerebellum.  This can be due to a variety of causes, with the most common being ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, multiple sclerosis, and vestibular migraines.  These are discussed in more detail in other articles.

Stroke



Vertigo may be a presenting sign of a brainstem stroke, usually due to hemorrhage or ischemia in the vertebrobasilar system (eg, posterior circulation).  Stroke is a medical emergency that must be quickly identified and managed.  Patients may present with sudden-onset, sustained vertigo, or with other signs and symptoms suggestive of stroke as the etiology, including:



  • Vascular risk factors:  Including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking
  • Focal neurologic deficits:  Stroke presenting with vertigo usually localizing to the brainstem (eg, lateral medullary syndrome) or cerebellum.  Common accompanying deficits may include ataxia, diplopia, dysarthria, weakness, and/or numbness.
  • Nystagmus with central features, including:
    • Pure vertical nystagmus:  Nystagmus in a central lesion can be any direction.  Pure vertical nystagmus rarely occurs in peripheral vertigo because conjugate vertical gaze is coordinated primarily in central neuronal tracts.
    • Not inhibited by fixation of gaze because it relates to a lesion that does not change with sensory input
    • No latency period
    • Not fatigable (>1 minute in duration)


Loss of consciousness is uncommon but can occur due to decreased perfusion to the reticular activating system (supplied by the basilar artery).  Patients with suspected stroke should undergo emergency neuroimaging; if hemorrhage is absent, stroke protocols with thrombolysis or antiplatelet therapy are standard, depending on the stroke type.

Multiple sclerosis



Vertigo that occurs due to a lesion from multiple sclerosis may be episodic and recurrent, with additional neurologic symptoms such as diplopia, limb weakness, or sensory changes.  Disease-modifying therapies (eg, interferon-beta) and symptomatic management for acute vertigo episodes are indicated.

Basilar migraine



Basilar migraines (cerebral vasospasm involving the brainstem) typically cause basilar aura symptoms, including vertigo, dysarthria, and/or tinnitus, without motor weakness, followed by a migraine-type headache.  Patients may have other features of migraine, including photophobia and/or phonophobia.  Prophylactic migraine therapy (eg, beta blockers, tricyclic antidepressants) and vestibular suppressants for acute episodes provide symptom control.

Differentiating central and peripheral causes of vertigo



The goal of the work-up of vertigo is to assess the likelihood of a central lesion (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
), which warrants further neuroimaging and potential time-sensitive interventions in cases of stroke.  Warning signs concerning for a central cause of vertigo (
figure 4
) include:



  • Associated neurologic signs and symptoms (eg, diplopia, dysarthria, ataxia, motor/sensory deficits)
  • New headache (or neck pain), particularly in posterior circulation strokes
  • Nystagmus with characteristics of central cause (see stroke section above), especially a purely vertical nystagmus
  • An abnormal HINTS (Head-Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew) exam (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ), a 3-part oculomotor examination that helps identify the location of the vestibular deficits
    • Peripheral cause:  Abnormal head-impulse test, unidirectional nystagmus, and no skew deviation
    • Central cause:  Normal head-impulse test, direction-changing or vertical nystagmus, and/or vertical skew deviation


Head imaging should be obtained urgently in all patients with concern for a central cause of vertigo.  CT scan is often obtained first because it can be completed faster than MRI.  However, if the CT scan is negative, MRI of the brain is usually required to exclude brainstem or cerebellum pathology (eg, diffusion restriction in stroke, demyelinating plaques in multiple sclerosis).



If a peripheral lesion is suspected, bedside tests of hearing (eg, Weber and Rinne) followed by confirmatory audiometry may be helpful in identifying the etiology of vertigo.

Differential diagnosis



Vertigo must be distinguished from other sensations that are often described by patients using similar terminology, such as imbalance, light-headedness, and other nonspecific descriptions.  These can be differentiated by description and their typical causes (

).

Summary



Vertigo is a symptom with diverse etiologies (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) requiring careful assessment to differentiate between peripheral and central origins.  Peripheral vertigo, seen in conditions such as benign paroxysmal positional vertigo and MÃ©niÃ¨re's disease, often presents with episodic vertigo and lacks neurologic deficits.  Central vertigo, caused by brainstem or cerebellar pathology, may present with subtle but critical neurologic signs.  Diagnostic approaches include clinical maneuvers, imaging, and sometimes audiometry, with management tailored to each specific condition.  Timely differentiation between benign peripheral causes and potentially life-threatening central causes is essential for optimal treatment and prognosis.
